summary: Edmundo Nobile (Enrique Rambal) invites friends over for an opulent dinner party. While the guests enjoy their food, the servants disappear one by one. Afterward, the visitors retire to the salon for an evening of music and conversation -- but in the morning, they are mysteriously incapable of leaving the room. As days go by and they run out of food and water, panic and madness set in. The army and the police arrive, but fail in their attempts to enter the house as conditions inside deteriorate.

reviews.content:
The surrealism and absurdity of this movie would be much less perplexing if you had watched Luis Buñuel's French movies. You would also probably ascertain that he has been essentially making the same film for over a decade.
You can interpret many motifs in this film since the eventual reason for their entrapment is kept purposefully unclear. Could it be a rich-vanity bubble that can only be escaped by adherence to their inane, never-ending rituals? The facade of high society etiquette that becomes irrelevant the moment the rich have to break a wall to get water (or apparently, as it was originally planned, resort to cannibalism)? Varied jabs at Franco's regime in Spain? It can be all of it. The main point is that, in the end, no one learned anything.
But aside from this metaphorical malarkey, is this story interesting to watch? I'd say yes. The short runtime of the movie and characters quickly acknowledging the absurdity of their situation help you not lose focus. Even if the first 15 minutes are just nameless figures greeting each other in purposeful scenes of repetition, followed by the practical survival of 20+ people in one room.

At first I thought this was one of those 1960s avant garde offerings that always bore me to death, but actually it's more like a ninety minute Twilight Zone episode.  One of the good Twilight Zone episodes, in fact.
A little forced at times and over dramatic as films of this era are known to sometimes be, however, still a fun little comedic film that passes the time.

I can't pretend I understood this one. Seemed to start like an Edgar Allen Poe horror and ended kind of anti climatically. Never got to the bottom of it and by the end didn't care much. Started well and then dissipated.

In "The Exterminating Angel," a state of empathy exists between the audience and the film's characters which is derived from a mutual feeling of frustration. In a creative parable involving the abysmal reality of having too much of a good thing, the film's key players rail and dwindle away amidst opulence that devolves into a state of savage primitivity. Despite a brilliant conceptual foundation and a sublimely satisfying conclusion, the film feels mercilessly strained, as though desperately trying to shake off its inevitable fate as a one-trick pony. Moments of comic and surreal brilliance periodically shine through, however the inescapable conclusion of this writer is that the film suffers from a lack of optimal formatting: like Bunuel's immaculately executed "Simon of the Desert," the present work may have functioned better in short form. In keeping with the reductive theme, narrowing the number of key players may also have strengthened our attachment to the story through greater familiarity with its central protagonists. As one of Bunuel's more misguided works, "The Exterminating Angel" intimates a level of brilliance that its restrictive plot structure unfortunately struggles to sustain.

What a boring , pointless movie.....
I'm sorry I dozed off during this film...

One of the better old horror films that has been stolen from over the years. Lots of symbolism. One thing though is I don't believe they all would've gone so crazy so fast. However, it was a very interesting plot kind of like a M Night Schymalan film. Basically, it was based off Spanish bourgeoise, and you can tell with comments like the poor don't suffer the same. I didn't really see it as a black comedy, now I can but to me it reminded me of a Spanish soap opera horror.

I'm not sure why, but I really enjoy both thematically dense films with some sort of supernatural element, and films that feature groups of people trapped in a single location for whatever reason to simmer in their shared misfortune; taken together, The Exterminating Angel is a slam dunk. 

Though its explicit intent is open to interpretation, Buñuel singles out some of his favorite targets for a bout of supernatural suffering, particularly the aristocratic class (though he can't help but bring the church into it at a later point); his handling of the conditions surrounding his characters' internment is brilliantly simple, requiring no added effects or excess - they are simply trapped in the room by an irresistible urge, subdued at first, but growing in intensity to the point where it cannot be ignored. The director then takes his time stripping away the veneer of respectability and class in social crusade, and with a style not unlike that of Lord of the Flies; allowing suppressed grievances to gradually be aired as the situation deteriorates. Caviar gets replaced with water from a burst pipe and sheep roasted over the remains of a cello. Biting stuff, but Buñuel takes care to leave the specific circumstances of a general criticism of the upper crust open to interpretation. 

And what an ending, with so many questions posed in the final scene. Such a great way to conclude a science fiction-esque surrealist threat, leaving the criteria for its activation vague, and the threat still very present. 

Buñuel's process must have caught the attention of animal rights groups by the '60s - the violence against his barnyard actors is only implied this time around. (4/5)

This true Buñuel masterpiece is made under his unmistakably flawless direction and presents his favourite theme of exposing and ridiculing the bourgeois mindset and way of life - with surrealist means, of course.

Buñuel it's the only director who makes political movies, (or at least movies that can be easily seen as metaphor for social dilemmas)  that aren't severe or staid, instead their absurdity  unleashes my hilarity as often as my most pure shock, and Buñuel does this in such a natural way that you follow him wherever he takes you.
Not only the drama, but the suspense and the mystery wraps the audience to the next level in this Luis Buñuel's remarkable film.
Reflexão em época de confinamento.
A magnificent satyrical and allegorical feature that is as pleasant to watch as it is to weave interpretations about it.

A fun and creative idea, with awesome characters and images. I loved it. I will admit that at times I got a little claustrophobic watching it, but nothing that wasn't easily overcome by some patience.
A bit confusing at the beginning. But confusion is the weapon of this film. Which ends in absolute thrill.

The Exterminating Angel is a weird, surreal film about how the aristocratic class is literally incapable of exiting its own little world and how it then becomes increasingly wretched. Bunuel was the rare artist whose work got more daring with age.

Buñuel clearly refuses to be subtle in this sharp allegorical satire (and because of that I only wish he had gone even further and embraced insanity and chaos all the way), using an absurd and quite ingenious idea to give a well-deserved slap on bourgeois values and hypocrisy.

Obviously serving as symbolism for what was occurring in Spain in the early 1960s, Brunel's film serves as satire of the most interesting sort. The film falls short in its ability to hold interest apart from its primary premise.

Buñuel tidak hanya berfantasi, tetapi juga bermain dengan segala simbolisasi dan kritik-kritik terpendam, seperti yang pernah coba dijelaskan Roger Ebert. Saya cukup mengagumi orisinalitas Buñuel yang berhasil membuat saya jengkel sepanjang film.
This is the worst shit ive ever seen. wtf are u people smoking???

"I adore things which go out of the ordinary," one of the ladies says, perhaps a reflection of what the audience is thinking.  The problem with most absurdities and farces is that they deal with some ridiculous situation which we either buy or don't buy.  Here, the situation is a mystery, servants suddenly leaving, everyone engaging in a giant slumber party, which is out of order for these people.  There's a bear and sheep in the house, a dead chicken in a purse.  A man is unconscious, dying perhaps.  "What's happening to us?" Doctor asks right before a thunderstorm.  It's intriguing, something is in the air and we don't know what it is, it's a total mystery.  It could be equally satisfying if we never find out.

Everything that once was sexy is now disgusting.  These people are filthy, un showered, their backends probably a mess. Where once we could picture a fairly sexy upper-class orgy, now we dream of escaping from one another.

The film is relentless, almost never letting go of the ever-increasing tension that drives these characters to madness.  We wonder to ourselves if there was something we missed - did they get trapped?  Barricaded by the people on the outside?  How did they suddenly start showing up?  Revelations come in the form of degenerating behavior while questions continue to be raised.  At no point do I lose interest in what's happening while still dying for answers, a perfect blend of engaging in experience while needing to know.  

We reach our most savage point when sheep are slaughtered, a dead couple are laughed at, and a royal rumble breaks out.  We wonder what satisfying solution could possibly come about, and most ideas that go through my head are unsatisfying.  But Bunuel works the unexpected, re-staging everyone exactly as they were before this mysterious curse trapped everyone.  One of the women is able to identify this, trying to guide everyone to retrace their steps until they can figure out what locked them in the first place - she equates the exercise to chess.  Eventually they stumble on a point in which someone declared it was time to retire, which seemed to generate a compulsive etiquette that resulted in the ensuing problem.

Time and space is a constant distortion - the couple thinks they've been their around a month, one of the ladies thinks they were at the opera "tonight."  The room seems to change positions.  The rest of the mansion becomes forbidden, they are locked in one space.  A black curtain forms, the homeowner on the other side.  Where exactly does the painting door lead to?  Bathroom?  Where is the bathroom anyway?  Sheep go upstairs, but arrive in the room where everyone is for their sacrifice.

Bunuels endless triad against the bourgeois. Here they are faced in a rather mysterious surrounding, being forced into all the unwanted horrors of the poor in a rather cramped and non-forgiving manner. Whats the grand idea behind this one-of-a-kind surreal nightmare, well one can only image, but its like thinking oneself out of prison. The destructive forces of the human mind vs the sacrificial lamb.

Such a strange, surreal, interesting and humourous film.  The premise is simple, a group of people at a formal dinner party realize that  they can't leave.  No real real reason is given.  Bunuel uses this story-line to skewer the upper-class.  This film won't be for everyone, but I enjoyed it.

Adoro o cinema de Buñuel, com sua crítica, surrealismo, direção seca, incômoda. Este aqui causa desconforto demais, especialmente pela condução muito aberta a interpretações, onde quase nada fica explícito.
One of Luis Buñuel's most well-known (if not his MOST well-known) surrealist satires, "The Exterminating Angel" is as bizarre and morbid as it is challenging to digest.

4.1/5

An interesting exploration of circumstances even as its symbolism and intentions overshadow its narrative and character as a film.

One night a group of wealthy aristocrats gathers to have a diner party. They eat, drink, & politely socialize, but when morning comes, for some inexplicable reason none of the guests can leave the party.  Trapped, the wealthy guests slowly begin to degenerate into savagery & brutality.  This macabre tale from surrealist filmmaker Luis Buñuel still delights because it illustrates all the hostility that lays under the surface of human "civilization" .  It's a must for fans of surreal cinema
The Exterminating Angel is darkly comedic, scathing observation of the violent impulses and terrible truths of high society when etiquette is stripped bare.

Ever had one of those dreams where you tried to leave a room, and couldn't? Yes, there's a movie about that. It's a pretty fun watch. Bunuel is the master of surrealist movies that masquerade as the conversational-dinner party movie. When the lambs heard together, you know s*** is about to go down.
I saw the movie, and i know... we are animals.

I've been pretty conflicted on what to rate The Exterminating Angel, on one side I felt compelled to give it a "positive" rating and bump it up half a star, but then I look at other films I have given this rating and almost all of them are better. The issue I had with this film is it kind of goes in streaks, of scenes I love and scenes I find dispensable. When it began, it felt somewhat choppy- I later understood the purpose of this- but regardless that is the affect it gave, making it hard to get into. Once the story began about the group of bourgeoisie members trapped in tan upscale room, it had many funny lines and ironic scenes. But as the film went along I felt that I was trapped in the same prison the characters were in, and just like everyone in the room wanted to get away from these idiots. By the time the hallucinations began I started enjoying the comedic work again, but there was a long point in the film where I couldn't wait for it to end. While I found the comedy successful the surrealism was clear but not effective. I love surrealistic pieces like Eraserhead or Un Chien Andalou- which Bunuel himself contributed too. But all the ones I love are eerie, dark, and symbolic. The surrealism in The Exterminating Angel, silly and weird but not eerie, dark, or symbolic. Bunuel has two obsession in his films, Christianity and the bourgeoisie. While there are funny moments regarding both categories, I can't distinguish his statement on either. Was the point that the bourgeoisie were becoming the working class, they once couldn't understand? Are they now the ones that are trapped, like their inferiors were once? That's the most I understood, but even their I can't complete the puzzle.
A wicked deconsrution of the upper class and their penchant for empty venality. Funny, disturbing, nasty, filmed with  the jaundice eye of a true cynic.Not to be missed by Bunuel fans...

A landmark movie, one that requires multiple viewings and has the ability to open up days of conversation on what the details in the film really mean. It's a conversation-starter, it's something that deliberately forces you to think outside the box, it's a fresh take on cinema...it's just a great movie.

I heard about this movie in "Midnight in Paris", but I couldn't rent it anywhere so I had to buy it. Absolutely loved it! At first I figured they couldn't leave because of social graces, but then the head servant couldn't leave as well. So then I thought maybe there was a real curse on the room (it is a movie, so anything is possible). And even though the movie dragged on, I just kept watching and watching because I seriously wanted to know what was holding them in the room, and how it was going to end. Were they going to die? Were they going to break the curse? And when someone finally figured out how to leave, I just burst out laughing! My first guess was the correct one! And then the church scene had me laughing even more! And I could certainly relate to being at a party and not knowing when it would be proper to leave, and dearly hoping someone else would excuse themselves first. Great movie! Bravo!

Mesmo que prejudicado por uma apresentação deveras apressada de personagens e uma trama que, mesmo contendo um teor filosófico imersivo, é questionável, não deixa de se tratar de uma obra altamente aprovável e gratificante graças ao seu estudo de certos comportamentos humanos - sem contar, é claro, sua iluminação fantástica que reflete adequadamente cada ponto do desenvolvimento da narrativa.

Even though the meaning of this thing officially beats me, I couldn't help but watch it with a big smile on my face. You've got people who can't leave the living room, and nobody knows why. Then there are some sheep and a bear running around. Whatever it is, it's good, if only for the sake of escaping reality and rules of logic for a while.
One of the greatest movies ever. All the horror, surrealism, and sociological analysis, with the means of "old" cinema.
Como en la película, los huéspedes no saben qué no les permite salir de la mansión. Yo no se que es lo que me atrae de ésta maravilla.

I agree with the New York Times reviewer here.  I would dare say Bunuel's social commentary is more or less the same in every film of his I have seen so far.  With that said, I do like the concept of people unable to leave a room with no explanation.  It's creepy and weird.  But then he shows a bunch of sheep and it's like "Oh, no shit, asshole.  Subtle."
A good concept, minus a few plot holes. Could've been great, but it feels slightly bloated and slow. Good dialog and a nice gimmick, using repetition to unnerve the viewer.

I love that Buñuel takes these characters seriously while placing them in the most absurd of scenarios. Like "Viridiana" this kind of consideration makes the satire more potent. I bet this film still makes members of the upper class angry.
A rather boring movie for starters but a masterpiece full of expressions and symbols and meanings for professionals.
a fucking masterpiece

A Bruñuel school's invitation is always becoming for any cinephile's reservoir, currently this film marks my fourth entrance into his territory after the lesser approachable THE MILKY WAY (1969, 6/10), THE EXTERMINATING ANGEL is an outstanding surrealism allegory, Bruñuel maneuvers a sleight of hand with sheer simplicity, the entire story is predominantly crammed in a living room of a regal mansion, the owners Lucía (Gallardo) and Edmundo (Rambal) host a dinner party for 20 middle-class guests. Bizarrely the party never ends, all of them, with the steward Julio (Brook) are incarcerated in the living room, whoever intends to get out of the room, will involuntarily alter his mind to stay, meanwhile for the people outside, the same mysteriously inexplicable force hedges them from entering too. 

Trapped in this claustrophobic space, the coexistence turns sour with time ruthless consuming the sustenance, the energy and the etiquette, simultaneously squabbles, vituperation, oneiric hallucinations, suicidal tendency and roughhousing all come to the fore (Bruñuel could go to extreme with cannibalism but he chose to refrain), the procedure of everyone takes off their facade and betrays their true self is excruciatingly riveting, the film could scale new heights as a superb probing essay on human nature if Bruñuel cared to exhume deeper to each character's meaty backstory (the fraternal hint, the flirtatious lady with terminal cancer, the undercurrent of adultery between the hostess and the Colonel, a votive trip to Lordes, the before/after reaction of taking the ulcer pills, not to mention the "La Valkiria" Leticia played by the first-billed Silvia Pinal, there are a slew of untold scandals are in need of elaboration). Instead the upshot is executed with a much murkier distinction, conspicuously they are all pawns in Bruñuel's storybook, it is rather an exacting task to distinguish all the different roles from a first-viewing, if only Robert Altman would do a remake, and expunge the political metaphor of the ending, then it would be transformed into a highly-watchable character analysis and an incisive farce with eye-dropping theatrical showpieces.

Of course Bruñuel's mastery is omnipresent in the film, the superimposition shot of a clear sky upon a facial portrait, the outlandish amalgam of lambs and a baby bear, and the creative approach to offer a vent to let them out (a Paradisi's sonata is the turning point), until the climax, we all realize it is just a trial run, and the denouement is a dual indictment on undiscerning religious belief and the political status quo at then, pepped up with a palpable feeling of hopelessness. 

Also the slap to the bourgeois is loud and clear since the film's opening, it is the servants who are sentient of the pending uncanniness, and urge to leave the house as soon as possible, only the obtuse are being entrapped by the almighty trickster. Then what happens to the hoi polloi in the church? The purge is more generic or we should merely stop over-interpretation? Anyway who needs a concrete answer as long as Bruñuel is concerned.

M-F-O

9.0

[Luis Buñuel]
[Mx]
A wonderful surrealist dream, one of the best of the films of Luis Buñuel.

An lesson on how to take a concept by the hand and run with it as fast as you can, The Exterminating Angel makes a nice plot contrast to The Discreet Charm Of The Bourgeoisie, but with the same thematics and style.
Bunuel's mesmerizing and ageless masterpiece.
Sarcasm at the level of mockery. Beautiful.

The Exterminating Angel serves as a very clever and interesting satire on the upper class members of society. Bunuel makes a bold and dark statement through this film and it makes for engaging viewing.

Monday, March 18, 2013

(1962) The Exterminating Angel
(In Spanish with English subtitles)
SOCIAL COMMENTARY DRAMA

Surrealist writer and director Luis Buñuel criticism about dictatorship which the film focuses on a group of well groomed heiresses and socialites who get together for a dinner, only that later they can't come to grips into leaving a particular area resulting to many disagreements.  Although I don't understand all it's nuances such as the dead chicken in the lady's purse, I still liked what I saw and may understand this film in the long run.

3.5 out of 4 stars
Remind me of The Mist. Very interesting to see the character studies.
way too macabre!!! very good!

Was just the myth nor hallucination of the echoes inside the golden mansion of the bourgeoisie, where lambs lament being chased down by bears that thoroughly lead food to the stake of the cannibals or really good elegant hypo critics? It was said by Silvia Pinal that Luis BAnuel was the Father and creator of the Exterminating Angel's true outside flesh: -it is just a reality show-; Banuel created reality shows...really? Cause I assume he did. Brilliant perception of nonsense, Transcendental and Surreal Black humor on Human's Nature persistent on wild partying all night long! - just scientifically speaking on what the hell just happened..
La mejor pelicula mexicana (y una de las mas absurdas) de la historia.
le je  suis tu'tamppeles le'anglais ze' el spaniol

One of the greatest films of Buñuel's career, and his last Spanish film, The Exterminating Angel is a contradiction. A meshing of dreams and reality, The Exterminating Angel is a kind of absolute reality-- a contradiction of dream and reality-- in a sort of "surreality" as André Breton would go on to write in his Surrealist Manifestoes. This film completely exemplifies the surrealist philosophy, with its arbitrary dark humour as an anti-bourgeois satire to the highest degree. If Breton and the surrealists were to put together a list of films that coincide with their ideology of a complete revolution, The Exterminating Angel would be at the top of the list. An absolute masterpiece in all aspects of cinema.

Bizarre, but brilliant. In order to watch this classic, you have to turn off the part of your brain that tells you that what's happening doesn't make sense. I'm still a little confused myself, though.
One of the best movies ever made.
great dark biting satire from the master
i dont know wats the brouhaha abt this film.its considered a masterpiece,but its nt my cup of tea.

Luis Buñuel, the master craftsman, dives deep into the darkest parts of the human psyche to create a perfectly executed film with satirical bite, brain jarring puzzlement & a presence that should stay with you long after.

Luis Bunuel film centering on socialites at a dinner party, after which retiring to the drawing room they are unable to leave (the wait staff beat a hasty retreat earlier.)  The trapped dinner party are forced to find ways to survive their cramped quarters, as food and water quickly run out, and no one on the outside can enter the premises.  More than just a survival story, the film is filled with repetitive acts and religious symbolism, and as what's really going on is left up to debate,the ending is no less powerful.  Recommended.

Probably my second favorite from Bunuel so far. It's comedic and also terrifying. Imagine one day you went to a party and entered a room and realized that you can't leave. Why can't you leave? I don't know, you just can't. And you can't figure it out either. So the best you can do is figure out where the water pipe is located and how you can find some food because it's going to be a long time before you're able to leave. Oh, and on top of that, imagine if people couldn't even come close to you. It's absurd, but also terrifying. Those who you were friends with at first might become your enemy, or those you disliked might be someone you come close to killing. That's the way this bourgeois group of people behave. They blame the host for the problem even though the host is stuck in there with them. How could this possibly benefit him? There is a young couple who have spent their first date at the opera and they were going to go home together afterword, but now they are stuck in this room. Luckily a doctor is present because an old man has difficulties breathing and seems to be slipping away. So what is Bunuel doing here? Putting a class of people in a room that he doesn't like and forcing them to reveal the horribleness at their core? That would be my best guess at least. Luckily there were sheep in the house as a joke for earlier. They find their way into the room, and the people end up eating them. One guy gives way to his sexual urges and ends up kissing a woman in her sleep. The young couple end up killing themselves in the closet. The old man dies and they put him in another closet. This story could take place over the span of a month or a few days. There's really no way to know. When we see them go to sleep we don't know if this is a new night, or perhaps they sleep more because there's nothing to do. If you look at it that way it becomes even more comedic. One of the women at the party realizes that they are all in the same position they were in the first night before they took off their jackets and went to sleep. So what does she do? Have them repeat everything in order to follow through with a different ending this time. This time, they are all going to say it's late and they must be heading out instead of sticking around for no apparent reason. This plan works, only for the same problem to occur once they are out. At the funeral the whole congregation seems to not be able to leave, and we get a flash forward where gunshots are heard. If I had a gun I would probably shoot myself if that happened to me twice. Imagine the fear of it happening to you repeatedly throughout your life! I liked the surreal aspects of the double entrance of the party guests and the animals that make their way through a house empty of people. This is Bunuel at his finest and should not go overlooked by an fan of surrealism.

¡Es una locura! El primer reality show, quizás, de México dirigida por Luís Buñuel y fotografiada por Gabriel Figueroa. Aquí el fuerte bien puede ser Silvia Pinal, pero nos damos cuenta de que no es una historia en la que alguien se lucirá como actor sino que será parte de un conjunto que dará un todo que se desvive en una gran metáfora sobre la voluntad y la fe, el origen de nuestras creencias y de nuestros valores. Una cinta en extremo interesante y bajo un ojo surrealista brillante.
what the heck was this movie about?
I should probably go home, but no one else is leaving, so I guess we're all going to starve. It's an utterly absurd premise, but Buñuel kind of pulls it off.

Equal to, if not greater than Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie. Stunning visuals, perfectly tied with it's dark surrealist comedy. As a whole, it is a perfect analysis of the human mind stripped bare from what the world has made us. As black as films can get. I have way to much to say about this film. A film that should be studied from for centuries to come.

Una alegoría del cinismo moral y la naturaleza humana, expresada en un lenguaje sarcastico que roza lo macabro
weirdly psychotic movie with a climax only a surrealist would understand and appreciate.
Great satire about the human proclivity to deny reality and live in a self-imposed bubble.
i saw this for the first time in my 10th grade spanish class.  i was the only person laughing.  quite simply this movie changed my life

Luis Bunuel was a master of the surreal and shocking and on his return to Spain in 1962 he made this odd ball mastepiece which serves as a bitter attack on the upper class.

A group of wealthy guests arrive at a dinner party just as all the servants decide to leave ,as the evening draws to a close the group for some reason cannot leave the dining room despite the fact all the windows and doors are open.

What follows is a slow slide into savagery which involes drinking water from a broken water pie and the killing of a flock of sheep that happen to be in the house.

Bunuel attacks his subject with bitter fury as we see how the simple rules of etiquette stifle this collection of dinner guests.

It is said that Salvador Dali was the master of surreal but to my mind its Bunuel who is the heart of soul of the surreal and this film proves just what a master craftsman he truly was.
http://how-girl-gets-ring-answers.com/trying-to-make-anyone-fall-love-you-find-effective-love-guide-singles
Very unusual but charmingly so. Oddly humourous and surprisingly captivating. Honestly had not heard of it until its mention in Midnight in Paris - very glad I did.
A brilliant (if pretentious) critique of the upper-class, the Catholic Church, and the comfortable little rooms we imprison ourselves in.
very twilight zone... seen the story line before. an enjoyable experience.
A Weird Surrealist and Metaphoric Movie, Criticizing the Behavior of the Bourgeois Class--Disturbing Dark Dangerous Satire!!
Another great film from Bunuel! Utterly silly and funny, I love how he pokes fun at the upper classes and their ridiculous codes of convention!  Excellent :)

Probably the most innovative movie ever.
This movie is sharp. 
Sardonicly denouncing the upper class manners, mixing bible elements with burgeoisie idiosyncrasies in a  claustrophobic scenario that makes it slightly horror.   
BIG inspiration for EVERYONE, this film is very Entertaining, and the "play" atmosphere (originally it was a script for a play), since it's all shot in the same location, gives the actors the chance to show their great skills.
By the superb director maestro  Luis Bunuel.

Solo BuÃ±uel pudo hacer unos salvajes despiadados de los mas ricos en Mexico, con una fotografia, edicion y direccion magistral El Angel Exterminador se consilida como una gran obra de arte con un guion maravilloso!
I couldn't leave the theater after watching it!

Was just the myth nor hallucination of the echoes inside the golden mansion of the bourgeoisie, where lambs lament being chased down by bears that thoroughly lead food to the stake of the cannibals or really good elegant hypo critics? It was said by Silvia Pinal that Luis BAnuel was the Father and creator of the Exterminating Angel's true outside flesh: -it is just a reality show-; Banuel created reality shows...really? Cause I assume he did. My take of the film is consideration and courtesy gone mad. They were all too polite and nervous about being inappropriate and minding the boundaries of decency that they ended up becoming burdened by their desire falling prey then flipping to the other side.
Bunuel's fiercest, most damning black comedy about bourgeois excess and human idiosyncrasies.
Bunuel the grandmaster, presents a mordant view of humanity, in this scathing attack on the bourgeoisie and the fickle nature of human behaviour...
Only saw it b/c of the reference in "Midnight in Paris" and ended up liking it and I'm not a surrealist cinema guy.
avasallante en cuanto se va generando un suspenso  paranoico.SILVIA PINAL FORMIDABLE,JACQUELINE ANDERE SENSACIONAL,AUGUSTO BENEDICO INOLVIDABLE Y VERDADERAMENTE GENIAL ES LUIS BUÃ'UEL,
Excelente obra de BuÃ±uel, con un planteamiento social y moral muy interesante sobre la naturaleza humana, imperdible obra.

Hardship, hunger, and real human desires....all from the comfort of a drawing room in a mansion. Why are they unable to leave the drawing room? Well, after dissecting the film my answer is who cares? It surely makes for a surrealist good time especially with the addition of sheep and a bear roaming the house. If this explanation isn't enough to spark your interest, I don't what is. You just have to really look past the absurdity of the film. The only problem I see arose with the amount of characters involved. It is hard to have a connection to any person in the room. Otherwise, the film is successful in its satirical, and did I mention surrealist type of way.

I know Luis Bunuel is supposed to be the master of black satire in film, and that this is supposed to be one of his best films, but for some reason I didn't enjoy it quite as much as I expected to. It's still a memorable and unique film, but it just didn't have the hammer-blow impact I thought it would. In case you were curious, this is the movie that Owen Wilson's character gives Bunuel the idea for in Midnight in Paris.

The premise is both simple and bizarre enough to really stand out. The movie has a bunch of wealthy socialites in a fancy mansion (doesn't it seem like all 1960s European art movies are about wealthy socialites?) who enjoy a dinner party, but then find themselves unable to leave the house, for no apparent reason. You know how sometimes when you're with a large group of people trying to decide what bar or restaurant to go to, but for some reason reaching a decision and going just seems impossible? These people have a life-threatening case of that. Things devolve as the days drag on, and social commentary is made. The large cast is good, but they're all 1960s Spanish actors that neither you nor I have ever heard of or will likely ever hear of again, so I won't bother discussing their performances.

I guess what bothered me was how surprisingly low-key and low-stakes the movie ended up feeling. I was hoping things would end up in blood orgies and cannibalism, but we didn't quite get there. By the time they leave, their clothes aren't even as shredded as I would have liked. Sure, some weird stuff happens, and some people do die, but of sickness or off-screen suicide. Plus, although the movie obviously wants to make a comment on people's hypocrisy, none of the characters are really fleshed out enough before their entrapment to convince us that their changes are so against their principles. You just have to go into the movie with a firm image of the bourgeoisie already in mind. I think the movie might have worked better for me with a smaller cast of more thoroughly developed characters, and had it gone to more outrageously absurd lengths. There's some great stuff here, don't get me wrong; but I wasn't as blown away by it as I had thought I would be.

Etiquette, manners and social pretense are a luxury for the class that never has to think about the basic amenities which are easily available to  them. When Bunuel robs them off their basic needs... the bourgeois people are stripped off their etiquette which are nothing but masks over another animal called 'Man' . Saw something like this in 'Nishijapon' by Sandip ray yrs ago... bt its no where near to be comparable.
Mr Bu?uel, I have a good idea for a good film.

The satire in this movie is so interesting. At times it's absolutely ruthless, going for the spine rather than the throat. Then it has wonderful surreal oddness from Bunuel(Chicken Purse?) And in a few scenes Bunuel is almost forgiving, as if he's recognizing that the bourgeoisie are just like everyone else, we're all morons in the grand scheme of things. It's been a few days since i've seen it and it continues to grow on me. I really regret shipping this out so quick, a second viewing is much needed.

En su momento fue una critica a la anquilosada alta clase social, hoy se puede leer como una advertencia para las clases domiantes encerradas en su circulo vicioso de poder, dinero y egoismo que los llevaran a su autodestrucciÃ³n. Me encanta. Interesante sus puntos surrealistas y sus dialogos descabezados pero con intenciÃ³n. Tremenda!

It's the best use of direct dialogue I've ever seen.

If the premise isn't that fresh the way Bunuel turns it into a black comedy, that has one great scene followed by another great scene and this goes on until it goes black, is fresh. In 'Midnight in Paris' the character of Woody Allen as played by Owen Wilson quips to Luis Bunuel, 'Then they're left there and we see who they truly are: animals' and he has it right; then jumping over to another Allen movie, 'Anything Else', the character of Jerry Falk is leaving the cinema with his girlfriend and one of the audience members says "Why didn't they just all leave after the dinner party?'. 'The Exterminating Angel' is a funny movie on us, humans, and what's beneath our veil. Bunuel's movie is an absurdist joke with no explanations and a blast to sit through.
I liked that it was tongue in cheek in a serious setting. An intriguing pathway into how deep the human condition stems.
Absurdist, surreal masterpiece from Bunuel.
Caught the reference in Midnight in Paris and had to watch it. A really terrifying, funny, unusual movie. Me likey.
Bunuel the grandmaster, presents a mordant view of humanity, in this scathing attack on the bourgeoisie and the fickle nature of human behaviour...

Not even Bunuel knows what directed and what it means, but this movie could have been a lot better without the ending church scene. It just raises more questions than it could have answered. The Exterminating Angel is a cinematic puzzle, full of satire, wit, and no easy answers. This is definitely one of those movies you take in again a few years later down the road to get a different perspective/angle.
Las palabras son insuficientes..

"The Exterminating Angel" is one of the most spectacularily strangest movies I have seen in many a long day. It starts out as an elegant dinner party for the upper class. Then, the servants go home and the guests are unable to function properly. They feel confined to the room in which they in and are unable to leave for no apparent reason. The doors are unlocked and the windows are open, yet they don't leave, starving themselves of food and water. It's crazy. Bizarre. Insane. Compulsively watchable and at times, very funny. So odd beyond belief, the sheep and the bears seemed amused by the guests' decent into utter madness. The ending is hilarious. After watching this, you'll be asking "What in the world?" Definately, a great film!
This film is essential a joke in the sense that BuÃ±uel throws in a lot of stuff just to confound the viewer and make himself laugh. The film works better, on a more sensory level almost.
